reviews.review:
[h1] I like Steam more than Valve, but this is the best Valve game without a doubt. [/h1]

It had always been in the 'Play Next' tab of my Steam Library ever since I played Portal 1 in 2019, but I'd always ignored it cause I didn't really feel like committing to a long puzzle game.

I have to keep telling myself that this is a [u]linear game[/u] because I've always been made disappointed when I try to explore or try something else even a bit. Every level in Portal 2 is a confined space with one task to achieve. 'Secret Areas' aren't really secret areas cause it's probably important to solving the puzzle. But the main thing is that if there's a straight path ahead, then that meant's you're not gonna achieve much by going to the left or right, which may irritate some people who are used to games with side objectives crammed in every nook and corner. But to be fair, Portal 1's radios were too excessive, and a linear design was probably the best way to go about in a 3-dimensional puzzle game such as this.

GLaDOS was the best character Valve had made during its prime. No one from Half-Life or their multiplayer games comes close to how amazing it felt when the autotuned robotic voice talked to me. Just like Gordon Freeman, Chell is also a silent protagonist, but she doesn't look like Heisenberg from Breaking Bad, so only her Orange jumpsuit can save her from losing to the free man himself.

[spoiler] There was some questionable level design at the end of chapter 4 where you're stuck in a room with 3 turrets and you had to find a small gap in the wall to shoot a portal to a wall far away, but aside from that, the level designs for the [i]'Modern Aperture'[/i] stages were great.[/spoiler]

As for the older [i]'Aperture Innovators'[/i] maps, I didn't like them as much. The modern labs were just like Portal 1 but detailed with decay, ruin, and organic growth due to being kept unmaintained for several years, which looked really atmospheric. Whereas the underground labs remind me of the plastic-feeling Source games of time's past. Other than the visuals, I was also not too happy with the new elements added for gameplay: The [b]bouncy[/b] and [i]speedy[/i] gels made me slightly motion-sick whenever I interacted with them (a very common quirk with Source‚Ñ¢ games), and when the cube is lathered with the gel, it got really hard to track them with my eyes whooshing around the entire room cause it kept bouncing off of the walls onto another. But the most pointless gameplay element of them all were the White and Clear gels (water I suppose). They could've just stopped with the Blue and Orange gels cause most of the time I just spammed the White gel on every surface I could find and then solve the puzzle with my brain afterward. Solving a puzzle with pre-determined portal-spaces was more fun than trial-and-error spilling the white gel everywhere. At least the Clear gel let me stop the bouncy cube from bouncing all over the place, so here's my final gel ranking: [b]Orange > Blue > Clear > White[/b]

After I finished the campaign, I was blown away cause I didn't have any other major hiccups during the game that warranted using a guide. The very next day, I tried the co-op with an online friend, did a couple of levels, and then didn't touch the game for another 3 months. I couldn't find anyone convenient to play with, so I played a few levels here and there until I got my old friend back, where we together tried to 100% all the co-op achievements. One [b]major[/b] issue in co-op was that you can't disable the in-game mic... This game gets random bug fix updates even in 2021, but they still couldn't fix an oversight that allowed you to use Discord or Steam VC without the audio echoing every time.

At least there weren't any game-long 'Collectibles' achievements like in other valve games. Most of them were restricted to a chapter at most.

[u]Final verdict:[/u] This was the best game created by Valve by a longshot. wouldn't play again though.
Best game in last 10 years, probe me wrong.

Very fun game, great story, great mechanics, great levels, overall just amazing. $10 is a steal, so if you haven't gotten it yet, it's 100% worth it. However, I recommend spending the extra $5 to get the bundle for both games since this game's story makes much more sense if you've completed the first game.

From what I have experienced so far, this game is really fun and is already becoming pretty difficult even though I started not long ago. The brain power required to beat some of the levels really makes this game unique and the story line is interesting too. The price for this game is quite cheap for what you get to experience so I really recommend this game!
